name: Human-Computer Interaction
coreConcepts: Usability -- the capacity of a system to provide a condition for its users to perform the tasks safely, effectively, and efficiently while enjoying the experience

User-centered Design -- a framework of processes in which usability goals, user characteristics, environment, tasks and workflow of a product, service or brand are given extensive attention at each stage of the design process. This attention includes testing which is conducted during each stage of design and development from the envisioned requirements, through pre-production models to post production.

Feedback -- the system's response to a user's action, providing information about what has been done and what has been accomplished. This communication helps users understand the result of their actions and whether their intended goals have been achieved

Affordances --  the properties of an object or interface that suggest how it can be used. In HCI, affordances are cues that help users understand what actions are possible with a digital interface or a physical object.

Consistency -- the principle that similar operations and elements should behave similarly within and across interfaces. This predictability helps users build mental models and reduces the learning curve when interacting with new systems.
Learnability -- how easy it is for users to accomplish basic tasks the first time they encounter the interface and how quickly they can reach proficiency.
Error Prevention & Handling -- design strategies that aim to reduce the likelihood of user errors and to make errors easy to recover from if they occur.
Accessibility -- the design of interfaces that ensure people of all abilities, including those with disabilities, can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with digital systems effectively.
keyProblems: Usability and Learnability: Designing interfaces that are easy to learn and use for diverse users.
Accessibility: Ensuring interfaces are usable by people with disabilities (e.g., visual, motor, cognitive impairments).
User Diversity: Accounting for differences in users’ age, culture, language, expertise, and preferences.
Context of Use: Designing for varied contexts (mobile, desktop, VR) and environments (noisy, multitasking).
Keeping Up with Technology: Rapidly evolving tech (e.g., AI, IoT, AR/VR) creates new interaction challenges.
Privacy and Security: Balancing data collection, user trust, and protection of sensitive data.
Emotional and Social Impact: Considering how interactions affect users’ emotions, well-being, and social behavior.
Cognitive Load: Minimizing mental effort required to use an interface.
Cross-Platform Consistency: Ensuring consistent experiences across devices and platforms.
applications: User Interface (UI) Design -- Designing interfaces for apps, websites, and software to make them intuitive and user-friendly.
Mobile & Web Applications -- Ensuring responsive and accessible interactions on smartphones, tablets, and browsers.
Virtual Reality (VR) & Augmented Reality (AR) -- Creating immersive environments with natural and engaging interactions.
Voice & Gesture Interfaces -- Applications like Siri, Alexa, and gesture-based controls in gaming and smart homes.
Assistive Technologies -- Designing tools for people with disabilities (e.g., screen readers, adaptive input devices).
Automotive Interfaces -- In-car entertainment systems, driver assistance, and safety features.
Healthcare & Telemedicine -- User-friendly systems for patient monitoring, medical devices, and remote consultations.
Smart Home & IoT Devices -- Designing interactions for home automation and connected devices.
E-learning & Educational Tools -- Interactive platforms and online learning environments.
Gaming -- Designing enjoyable and immersive experiences, especially in interactive storytelling and motion-based controls.
tools: Figma / Sketch / Adobe XD → Widely used for designing and prototyping user interfaces.
Axure / Balsamiq → Wireframing and low-fidelity prototyping.
UserTesting / Lookback.io → Tools for remote usability testing and gathering user feedback.
Eye-tracking tools (Tobii Pro, EyeLink) → Analyze user gaze behavior to inform design.
Miro / MURAL → Collaborative whiteboards for ideation and user journey mapping.
Unity / Unreal → Engine Developing interactive 3D/VR/AR experiences.
p5.js → JavaScript library for creating interactive visual content.
D3.js → For creating dynamic and interactive data visualizations.
Three.js → Web-based 3D visualizations, often used in VR/AR prototypes.
OpenCV → Computer vision library, useful for gesture-based or camera-based interaction.
timeline: 1950s – Early batch processing; no direct user interaction.
1963 – Ivan Sutherland develops Sketchpad, first graphical user interface (GUI).
1964-1968 – Douglas Engelbart’s “Mother of All Demos”: Introduces mouse, hypertext, and window-based interaction.
1973 – Xerox Alto: first computer designed for personal use with GUI.
1979-1983 – Apple Lisa and later Macintosh popularize the GUI in personal computing.
1983 – The Psychology of Human-Computer Interaction (Card, Moran, Newell) defines HCI as a research domain.
1984 – CHI Conference (ACM SIGCHI) becomes the major HCI conference.
1986 – Ben Shneiderman’s direct manipulation principles are formally described.
1990s – WWW (World Wide Web) emerges, expanding HCI to web-based interactions.
